terms.term: Outline what’s meant by SLT 2 marks
terms.definition: SLT is an extension of Behaviourism and involves learning through observation as investigated by Bandura who took into account cognitive processes between a stimulus and response eg. Thoughts emotions attention retention etc.

Social learning theory (SLT) is learning through observation as investigated by Bandura, and is an extension of Behaviourism. It considers mediational processes (eg. Retention - the extent to which behaviour has been remembered) which occur between the stimulus and response, otherwise ignored by the Behaviourist approach. Imitation (replicating the behaviour of others) as outlined by SLT, depends on 2 factors which makes imitation more likely: vicarious reinforcement (indirect learning through observation of consequences of another person’s behaviour) and identification (extent to which person relates to individual being observed eg. Same sex, high status.) Through Bandura’s 1961 Bobo Doll study, he found evidence to support the hypothesis that children who passively observe aggressive behaviour from adults are more likely to imitate that behaviour and act aggressively themselves.

One strength of SLT is that it acknowledges mediational processes and the idea that thinking occurs before acting which is seen to be a more realistic account of how humans learn. Cognitive processes such as attention, retention, motor reproduction and motivation as theorised by Bandura involve noticing behaviour, remembering it, being able to reproduce the behaviour and the desire to do so. This would suggest that humans don’t solely learn by personal experience, but also by observing the consequences of other’s actions when deciding how to further behave (VR.) Moreover, the theory of mediational processes support SLT as it is a more comprehensive explanation of human behaviour than classical and operant conditioning, therefore acting as a valuable extension to behaviourism in the world of psychology. 
Despite this, a weakness of  SLT is that it does not consider biological factors in learning. For example, Bandura’s findings in his research concerning observational learning may actually be a result of  mirror neurones in the brain which allow us to empathise with and imitate others. This suggests that SLT is not a fully comprehensive learning theory as biology is under-emphasised.

terms.term: A03: EVAL: para 3 16m : practical application eg. Media
terms.definition: Another benefit of SLT is that is can be applied to real world situations in providing an explanation in how behaviour is learned and therefore can aid us in improving society as a whole. In Bandura’s bobo doll experiment which supports SLT, a major finding was that children who observed an adult displaying aggressive behaviour towards the doll drastically increased the likelihood of them displaying aggression almost identical to that which they witnessed. This suggests that children are incredibly impressionable and this evidence has proved to be invaluable in understanding our society and working towards making the world a better place. This was demonstrated through the changing of times when explicit movies (eg. Swearing, horror genre etc.) were shown in order to limit exposure to children, as well as the increase in age ratings on video games which involve violence. These media changes work to decrease violence and anti-social behaviour as a direct result of Bandura’s shocking findings used as evidence to support SLT, outlining the significance of SLT in ameliorating society.

Another weakness of SLT is that its main supporting evidence, Bandura’s Bobo doll study, can be said to lack ecological validity (the extent to which findings reflect real-world scenarios) given that it occurred  in a highly controlled lab-setting out of a human’s natural environment, increasing the likelihood of abnormal behaviour. As well as this, the Bobo doll used can be said to be a demand characteristic (cues in a study which may reveal true purpose to participants, leading to altered behaviour) as its main purpose is to be hit, an act of aggression. This adds an extra variable which influences aggressive behaviour, therefore reducing the validity of the experiment as a clear cause and effect relationship becomes less defined. Overall, SLT can be said to be less valid as its evidential study tells us little about how children learn, let alone adults in the real world.

terms.term: Briefly explain 2 strengths and 2 weaknesses of the cognitive approach
terms.definition:
6. One strength is the use of lab studies as it increases the internal validity of the experiment since it is highly controlled method of research. This results in increased validity of the evidence supporting the cognitive approach, therefore increasing the validity and comprehensiveness of the approach as a whole as a clear cause and effect relationship is easily established. 
	One strength is its use of theoretical models to represent internal mental processes. This is a strength because of the ease with which they can be understood due to the simple flow diagram format. Eg, input -> mental event -> output
	One limitation is that mental processes is not directly observed, given that inferences are indirectly concluded about observable behaviour. This suggests that the approach is less valid as it is not based on observable fact. 
	One limitation is that it could be criticised as being overly mechanistic eg. Likening the workings of the mind to that of a computer. This is a weakness because it oversimplifies complexity of the human mind such as emotions and motivation, to operating like unemotional wires and hard drives.

Evidence to support the genetic explanation of behvaiour comes from calculating concordance rates (extent to which two people share the same characteristic). Higher concordance rates are often found for monozygotic twins than dizygotic as they are 100% identical in terms of genes..

terms.term: How do biologists suggest that evolution can explain our behvaiour?

Attachment behaviours in new horns aid their survival.

+) One strength of the biological approach is that it has beneficial real world applications such as aiding the development of drug therapy to improve the lives of people suffering with mental disorders. Through the biological approach psychologists  investigated into the role of neurotransmitters (eg. Hormones) in influencing behaviour. For example, we know that imbalances in serotonin can cause mood swings and when severely low, can cause depression. As a result of this conclusion psychoactive drugs (eg. SSRIs) have been developed to treat people. Although they are not effective for everyone they can improve the quality life of many by reducing suffering and are therefore a strength of this approach.
